awd_titl_txt: Mechanistic Studies of Dipole Effects on Electronic Coupling in Charge Transfer Implemented as Photoinduced Dynamics of Intramolecular Hole Hopping
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Valentine Vullev at the University of California, Riverside is developing new classes of synthetic systems to study the influence of dipoles on charge transfer.   Charge transfer is among the most fundamental processes, essential for managing energy flow and sustaining life on Earth. Respiration, photosynthesis, batteries, electronic devices and many other intricate components of lives heavily rely on efficient charge-transfer processes. Concurrently, electric dipoles are everywhere, and the localized fields around them can have a profound effect on how charges move.  Therefore, it is important to understand how dipoles affect charge transfer, in order to enhance desired forward electron transduction while suppressing undesired processes.   Professor Vullev's group is well positioned to provide the highest level of education and training for students, including those underrepresented in science.   Outreach activities involving K-12 students are planned.   Summer research training, which includes writing scientific papers and producing scientific videos, will be provided for high school students.  

More specifically, the goal of this project is to explore how dipoles affect electronic coupling in charge-transfer systems in bioinspired molecular electrets, which are systems with ordered electric dipole moments.  The research is based on Professor Vullev's discovery that the dipoles of molecular electrets can modulate the delocalization of frontier orbitals and alter donor-acceptor electronic coupling, leading to orders of magnitude changes in the charge-transfer rates.  It has three specific aims: (1) determining parameters that govern dipole-modulated electronic coupling; (2) determining the dipole effects on charge transfer occurring via hole-hopping vs. tunneling mechanisms; and (3) determining the effect of radical delocalization on the dynamics of hole hopping.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Charge transfer is crucially important for sustaining life on Earth and for making our modern ways of living possible (Phys. Chem. Chem. Phys. 2020, 22, 21583-21629). Photosynthesis and respiration cannot function with precise transduction of charges to ensure the vital energy flow in living organisms. It is challenging to imagine life without batteries, computers, video displays and other electronic devices that all depend on efficient charge-transfer processes. The importance of understanding the factors that control charge transfer, therefore, cannot be overstated. This project explores the effects of molecular dipoles for enhancing the efficiency of desired charge-transfer steps and suppressing the undesired ones. Electric dipoles are ubiquitous warranting the need for deep understanding of how they affect the phenomena around us. A principal discovery from this project is that the dipoles affect not only the initial and final stages of movement of charges, but also the (electronic-coupling) pathways by which they move. As a result, rates of transfer of negatively charges toward the positive poles of dipoles can be slower than toward the negative poles. As counterintuitive as this outcome may appear, it provides new paradigms of thinking about charge transfer.

The accepted notion of how electric dipoles affect charge-transfer rates focuses solely on the thermodynamic driving forces. That is, a permanent dipole oriented from an electron donor to an electron acceptor stabilizes the charge-transfer state and enhances the rates in the normal region. Conversely, a dipole pointing from the acceptor to the donor decreases the charge-transfer rates (Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 2018, 57, 12365-12369). (The orientation of electric dipoles is from their negative to their positive poles.) A principal assumption in this line of thinking is that the dipole does not affect the donor-acceptor electronic coupling. This project revealed the shortcomings of this assumption and showed examples where the dipole effects on electronic coupling prevail over its effects on the thermodynamic diving force. Since the designed studies were on photoinduced charge separation and hole transfer, the project led to breakthroughs in molecular photonics and in development of redox-resistant building blocks for long-range charge transfer. To benefit from the photogenerated charges, it is important for them to have relatively large energy so that they drive chemical transformations at high potentials. In this respect, amides are some of the worst hole transducers because they tend to undergo irreversible oxidative degradation at potentials around 1.4 V vs. SCE. This project demonstrated that ether groups and pi-delocalizing aromatic moieties can stabilize the radical cations of anthranilamides leading to reversible oxidation at potentials exceeding 1.5 V vs. SCE. The extensive mechanistic studies also led to breakthrough of using change transfer for controlling the photophysics of molecular species. Anti-Kasha behavior and white fluorescence originating from tuning the donor-acceptor electronic coupling are some of the examples for such outcomes (JACS Au 2023, 3, 1918-1930; Chem. Sci. DOI: 10.1039/d3sc03812b). Nitroaromatics do not fluoresce. It is a reasonable and broadly accepted notion because the nitro groups provide efficient pathways for intersystem crossing, which compete with the radiative deactivation, i.e., with the fluorescence. Nevertheless, a close look at the mechanism of the spin flips involving transfer of an electron between orbitals with different momenta, reveals a potential means for suppressing the triplet formation that nitro groups induce (J. Mater. Chem. C 2022, 10, 2870-2904). Employing this understanding allows making compounds like nitronaphthalene, with signet-excited-state lifetime of about 100 fs, fluoresce (J. Phys. Chem. Lett. 2021, 12, 10295-10303). Tuning the electronic coupling with the nitro groups provides another means for fluorescent nitro compounds (Commun. Chem. 2020, 3, 190). When everything is perfectly aligned to produce nitroaromatics with high fluorescence quantum yields, alternative pathways of non-radiative deactivation, such as aborted photochemistry, can emerge, which is a key discovery under this project (Chem. Sci. 2021, 12, 14039-14049). In the process of improving the characterization of charge-transfer systems, this project led to methods for broadening the applicability of electrochemical analysis for extracting meaningful information and addressing inherent systematic errors (e.g., J. Electrochem. Soc. 2019, 166, H3175; Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA 2021, 118, e2026462118; Curr. Opin. Electrochem. 2022, 31, 100862; J. Phys. Chem. B 2023, 127, 1443-1458). These new developments not only have broad utility, but also provide important information about the properties of surfaces and interfaces.

The discovered dipole effects on electronic coupling sets new paradigms for charge transfer. Following the theme of charge transfer and electronic coupling, this project led to outcomes with broad impacts on electrochemistry, photonics and materials design. This project provided training to a diverse group of graduate students, postdocs and undergraduate students. Some of them already hold faculty positions. Successful outreach under this project allowed recruiting high-school students from California and Massachusetts who worked as internes and received extensive hands-on research experience.


Last Modified: 11/25/2023
Modified by: Valentine I Vullev
